item.title: Robin add a quote by Lynda Barry
item.description: "No matter what, expect the unexpected. And whenever possible BE the unexpected." -- Lynda Barry

item.title: Robin add a quote by David Milch
item.description: "Pain or damage don't end the world. Or despair, or fucking beatings. The world ends when you're dead. Until then, you've got more punishment in store. Stand it like a man... and give some back." -- David Milch

item.title: Robin add a quote by George Santayana
item.description: "The muffled syllables that Nature speaks Fill us with deeper longing for her word; She hides a meaning that the spirit seeks, She makes a sweeter music than is heard." -- George Santayana

item.title: Robin add a quote by Cormac McCarthy
item.description: "You think when you wake up in the mornin yesterday don't count. But yesterday is all that does count. What else is there? Your life is made out of the days it’s made out of. Nothin else." -- Cormac McCarthy

item.title: Robin add a quote by Ludwig Wittgenstein
item.description: "I don't know why we are here, but I'm pretty sure that it is not in order to enjoy ourselves." -- Ludwig Wittgenstein

item.title: Robin add a quote by George Santayana
item.description: "Everything in nature is lyrical in its ideal essence, tragic in its fate, and comic in its existence." -- George Santayana

item.title: Robin add a quote by Katherine Dunn
item.description: "The child, screaming for refuge, senses how feeble a shelter the twig hut of grown-up awareness is. They claim strength, these parents, and complete sanctuary. The weeping earth itself knows how desperate is the child's need for exactly that sanctuary. How deep and sticky is the darkness of childhood, how rigid the blades of infant evil, which is unadulterated, unrestrained by the convenient cushions of age and its civilizing anesthesia. Grownups can deal with scraped knees, dropped ice-cream cones, and lost dollies, but if they suspected the real reasons we cry they would fling us out of their arms in horrified revulsion. Yet we are small and as terrified as we are terrifying in our ferocious appetites." -- Katherine Dunn

item.title: Robin add a quote by Dr. Seuss
item.description: "You have brains in your head. You have feet in your shoes. You can steer yourself any direction you choose. You're on your own. And you know what you know. And YOU are the one who'll decide where to go..." -- Dr. Seuss

item.title: Robin add a quote by Thucydides
item.description:
"For the whole earth is the tomb of famous men; not only are they commemorated by columns and inscriptions in their own country, but in foreign lands there dwells also an unwritten memorial of them, graven not on stone but in the hearts of men. Make them your examples, and, esteeming courage to be freedom and freedom to be happiness, do not weigh too nicely the perils of war."
[Funeral Oration of Pericles]" -- Thucydides

item.title: Robin add a quote by David Lynch
item.description: "These growth hormones, where can I get a bunch of them? Is there some way that, with electricity, you could stimulate your own growth hormones? Plug yourself in for five minutes, there'd be a little jolt, but you'd get used to it. It wouldn't be bad at all; in fact, you'd get to enjoy it, probably. Then away you'd go, and youth wouldn't be wasted on the young anymore. You'd be 25, with a 95-year-old mind. Granddad would start breaking into liquor stores and staying out late. Hope we have it soon!" -- David Lynch

item.title: Robin add a quote by Samuel Beckett
item.description: "You're on Earth. There's no cure for that." -- Samuel Beckett

item.title: Robin add a quote by Samuel Beckett
item.description: "All of old. Nothing else ever. Ever tried. Ever failed. No matter. Try again. Fail again. Fail better." -- Samuel Beckett

item.title: Robin add a quote by Samuel Beckett
item.description: "How hideous is the semicolon." -- Samuel Beckett

item.title: Robin add a quote by George Santayana
item.description: "To knock a thing down, especially if it is cocked at an arrogant angle, is a deep delight of the blood." -- George Santayana

item.title: Robin add a quote by Cormac McCarthy
item.description: "Anything that doesn't take years of your life and drive you to suicide hardly seems worth doing." -- Cormac McCarthy

item.title: Robin add a quote by Tom Stoppard
item.description: "Traitors hoist by their own petard?--or victims of the gods?--we shall never know!" -- Tom Stoppard

item.title: Robin add a quote by Plato
item.description: "Be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a harder battle." -- Plato

item.title: Robin add a quote by Neal Stephenson
item.description: "Show some fucking adaptability!" -- Neal Stephenson

item.title: Robin add a quote by David Foster Wallace
item.description: "Because here's something else that's weird but true: in the day-to day trenches of adult life, there is actually no such thing as atheism. There is no such thing as not worshipping. Everybody worships. The only choice we get is what to worship. And the compelling reason for maybe choosing some sort of god or spiritual-type thing to worship -- be it JC or Allah, be it YHWH or the Wiccan Mother Goddess, or the Four Noble Truths, or some inviolable set of ethical principles -- is that pretty much anything else you worship will eat you alive. If you worship money and things, if they are where you tap real meaning in life, then you will never have enough, never feel you have enough. It's the truth. Worship your body and beauty and sexual allure and you will always feel ugly. And when time and age start showing, you will die a million deaths before they finally grieve you. On one level, we all know this stuff already. It's been codified as myths, proverbs, clichés, epigrams, parables; the skeleton of every great story. The whole trick is keeping the truth up front in daily consciousness." -- David Foster Wallace

item.title: Robin add a quote by Maude Newton
item.description: "Where the craving for admiration and approval predominates, intellectual rigor cannot thrive, if it survives at all." -- Maude Newton

item.title: Robin add a quote by John Dewey
item.description: "The self is not something ready-made, but something in continuous formation through choice of action." -- John Dewey

item.title: Robin add a quote by John Dewey
item.description: "There's all the difference in the world between having something to say, and having to say something." -- John Dewey

item.title: Robin add a quote by John Dewey
item.description: "The path of least resistance and least trouble is a mental rut already made. It requires troublesome work to undertake the alteration of old beliefs. " -- John Dewey

item.title: Robin add a quote by John Dewey
item.description: "Conflict is the gadfly of thought. It stirs us to observation and memory. It instigates invention. It shocks us out of sheep-like passivity, and sets us at noting and contriving…conflict is a sine qua non of reflection and ingenuity." -- John Dewey

item.title: Robin add a quote by John Dewey
item.description: "The only freedom that is of enduring importance is the freedom of intelligence, that is to say, freedom of observation and of judgment, exercised in behalf of purposes that are intrinsically worth while. The commonest mistake made about freedom is, I think, to identify it with freedom of movement, or, with the external or physical side of activity." -- John Dewey

item.title: Robin add a quote by John Dewey
item.description: "a problem well put is half solved." -- John Dewey

item.title: Robin add a quote by John Dewey
item.description: "The good man is the man who, no matter how morally unworthy he has been, is moving to become better." -- John Dewey

item.title: Robin add a quote by John Dewey
item.description: "To me faith means not worrying" -- John Dewey

item.title: Robin add a quote by John Dewey
item.description: "Give the pupils something to do, not something to learn; and the doing is of such a nature as to demand thinking; learning naturally results." -- John Dewey

item.title: Robin add a quote by John Dewey
item.description: "Of all affairs, communication is the most wonderful." -- John Dewey
